text: Applications

1. Look for rep-tile patterns in the following designs. For each design, do the following:

  • Decide whether the small quadrilaterals are similar to the large quadrilateral. Explain.
  • If the quadrilaterals are similar, give the scale factor from each small quadrilateral to the large quadrilateral.

a. No, they are not similar. One of the small figures is a square, so it does not have the same shape as the original rectangle, which is not a square.

b. Yes, they are similar because their corresponding interior angles are congruent. Also, each side of the smaller quadrilateral increases by the same scale factor to form the larger quadrilateral. The side lengths of the larger shape are double that of the smaller shape, so the scale factor is 2.

c. Yes, they are similar because their corresponding interior angles are congruent. Also, each side of the smaller quadrilateral increases by the same scale factor to form the larger quadrilateral. The side lengths of the larger shape are triple that of the smaller one, so the scale factor is 3.

d. Yes, they are similar because their corresponding interior angles are congruent. Also, each side of the smaller quadrilateral increases by the same scale factor to form the larger quadrilateral. The side lengths of the larger shape are double that of the smaller one, so the scale factor is 2.

2. Suppose you divide a rectangle into 25 smaller rectangles such that each rectangle is similar to the original rectangle.

a. How is the area of each of the smaller rectangles related to the areas of the original rectangle?

The area of each small rectangle is 1/25 the area of the large rectangle.

Note: You might suggest that students provide a sketch to verify their answer.
b. What is the scale factor from the original rectangle to each of the smaller rectangles?

3. Look for rep-tile patterns in the following figures.

  • Tell whether the small triangles are similar to the large triangle. Explain.
  • If the triangles are similar, give the scale factor from each small triangle to the large triangle.

a. The small triangles are similar to the large triangle because the corresponding angles of the triangles are congruent. The scale factor is 2.

b. The small triangles on the left and right corners are similar to the large triangle with scale factor 2, but the other two small triangles are not similar to the large triangle. Since the non-similar triangles are not formed by the connection of midpoints, we cannot assume that the triangles are similar.

c. None of the small triangles are similar to the large one.

d. The small triangles are similar to the large triangles since the angles in each small triangle are congruent to the angles in the large triangle. The scale factor is 2.

Note: You can compare this figure with the figure from part a. They look different, but their constructions are essentially the same.

4.

a. For Rectangles E, F, and G, give the length and width of a different, similar rectangle. Explain how you know the new rectangles are similar.

b. Give the scale factor from each original rectangle in ACE 4a to the similar rectangles you described. Explain what the scale factor tells you about the corresponding lengths, perimeters, and areas.

Answers will vary.

Rectangle E:

a. Any rectangle with dimensions 6k by 12k, where k is any positive number, is similar to Rectangle E. The ratio of the corresponding sides will be the same.

b. The scale factor from Rectangle E to the new rectangle is k. The side lengths and perimeter of the new rectangle are k times the corresponding lengths and perimeter of Rectangle E. The area of the new rectangle is k² times the area pf Rectangle E.

Rectangle F:

a. Any rectangle with dimensions 4k and 10k, where k is any positive number, is similar to Rectangle F. The ration of the corresponding sides will be the same.

b. The scale factor from Rectangle F to the new rectangle k. The side lengths and perimeter of the new rectangle are k times the corresponding lengths and perimeter of Rectangle F. The area of the new rectangle is k² times the area of Rectangle F.

Rectangle G:

a. Any rectangle with dimensions 6k and 4k, where k is ant positive number, is similar to Rectangle G. The ratio of the corresponding sides will be the same.

b. The scale factor from Rectangle G to the new rectangle is k. The side lengths and perimeter of the new rectangle are k times the corresponding lengths and perimeter of Rectangle G. The area of the new rectangle is k² times the area of Rectangle G.
5. Suppose Rectangle B is similar to Rectangle A. The scale factor from Rectangle A to Rectangle B is 4. What is the area of Rectangle B?

192 cm²

The side lengths of Rectangle B are 12 cm (3 cm x scale factor 4) and 16 (4 cm x scale factor 4). So, the area of Rectangle B is 12 x 16 = 192 cm².

Or, when the scale factor from A to B is 4, the area of B will be 4² times larger than the area of A. Since the area of A is 3 cm x 4 cm = 12 cm², the area of B is 4² x 12 cm² = 192 cm²

6. Suppose rectangle E has an area of 9 square centimeters and Rectangle F has an area of 900 square centimeters. The two rectangles are similar. What is the scale factor from Rectangle E to Rectangle F?

10; The area of Rectangle F is 100 times greater than the area of Rectangle E. Since 10 x 10 = 100, the scale factor from E to F will be 10.

For example, Rectangle E can be 3 by 3 square and Rectangle F can be 30 by 30 square. They are similar are areas are 9 and 900, respectively. The scale factor from E to F will be 10.
7. For ACE 7a-c, use the grid below each problem.
a. Sketch a triangle similar to Triangle X with an area that is 1/4 the area of Triangle X.
base: 2.5, height: 2.5
b. Sketch a rectangle similar to Rectangle Y with a perimeter that is 0.5 times the perimeter of Rectangle Y.
base: 1.5, height: 2
c. Sketch a parallelogram similar to Parallelogram Z with side lengths that are 1.5 times the side lengths of Parallelogram Z.
base: 9 ; height: 3
8. Use the following polygons.
a. List pairs of similar shapes.
Rectangle H and P, Triangles R and Q, and Parallelograms M and N.
b. For each pair of similar shapes, find the scale from the smaller shape to the larger shape.
The scale factor from H to P is 2, from R to Q is 6/4 or 3/2, and N to M is 6/4 or 3/2.
9. Triangle ABC is similar to triangle PQR. Find the indicated angle measure or side length.
a. angle A
b. angle Q
64°; The measure of angle Q is same as the corresponding angle B since two triangles are similar.
c. angle P
67°; The measure of angle P is same as the corresponding angle A.
d. length of side AB
38 in.; The scale factor from Triangle PQR to Triangle ABC is 2. Side AB is two times longer than its corresponding side, PQ.
e. length of side AC
45 in.; The length of side AC is twice the length of PR.
f. perimeter of triangle ABC
129 in.; Perimeter of triangle ABC is the sum of side lengths, AB + BC + CA: 38 + 46 + 45 = 129

10.

Multiple Choice

Use the similar parallelograms.

A. What is the measure of angle D?

A. 55°

B. 97.5°

C. 125°

D. 135°
C; The angle D corresponds to the angle Q

B. What is the measure of angle R?

A. 55°

B. 97.5°

C. 125°

D. 135°
F; The angle R corresponds to the angle A.

C. What is the measure of angle S?

A. 55°

B. 97.5°

C. 125°

D. 135°
C; The measure of angle S is same as the measure of angle Q, because it is a parallelogram.

D. What is length of side AB?

A. 3.75cm

B. 13cm

C. 15cm

D. 26cm
H; The length of side AB is equal to the length of side CD, because it is a parallelogram.
11. Evan, Mariana, and Shaun discuss whether the Figures E and F are similar. Do you agree with Evan, Mariana, and Shaun? Explain.

Evan's Reasoning

Rectangles E and F are similar because each shape has four right angles. Also, each rectangles has at least one side that is 12 meters long.

Mariana's Reasoning

The scale factor for the height from Rectangle E to Rectangle F is 12/9 or 4/3. The scale factor for the base is 15/12, or 5/4.

4/3 ≠ 5/4, so the rectangles are not similar.

Shaun's Reasoning

Rectangles E and F are similar. Rectangle F is 3 meters taller than Rectangle E since 9 meters + 3 meters = 12 meters. Rectangle F is also 3 meters wider than Rectangle E since 12 meters + 3 meters = 15 meters. Each dimension of Rectangle F is 3 meters greater than the corresponding dimension of Rectangle E, so the rectangles are similar.

Mariana is correct. In order for the shapes to be similar, they must have consistent scale factors, which they do not.

Evan is incorrect. Evan's reasoning highlights the difference between polygons in general and the specific case of triangles. With triangles you can determine similarity just by comparing corresponding angles, but this does not always work with other figures.

Shaun is incorrect. Shaun's thinking is a common mistake for many students. Shaun thinks that an additive relationship of the sides indicates similarity, rather than a multiplicative relationship.
12. Janine, Nola, and Jeff drew parallelograms that are similar to Parallelogram P.
Each student claims that the scale factor from P to the sketched parallelogram is 4. Are any of the students correct in their reasoning?

Janine's Method

I divided the original parallelogram into four similar parallelograms. Parallelogram P is four times as large as each of the new parallelograms.

Nola's Method

I sketched four copies of Parallelogram P. The shape has four times the area of Parallelogram P.

Jeff's Method

I wanted a scale factor of 4. The perimeter of the original shape is 26 centimeters. I drew a parallelogram with a perimeter of 4 x 26 centimeters = 104 centimeters

Jeff is correct in his reasoning. When a scale factor is applied in a figure, it is applied to lengths. Jeff's perimeter is 4 times as great as the perimeter of the original parallelogram.

Janine applied a scale factor of 1/2 and Nola applied a scale factor of 2.

13. Maya lies on the ground 45 feet from her tent. Both the top of the tent and the top of a tall cliff are in her line of sight. Her tent is 10 feet tall. About how high is the cliff? Assume the two triangles are similar.

About 98.9 feet; Compare the corresponding side lengths of the similar triangles: 45 ft corresponds to 45 + 400 ft, which means the scale factor from the smaller triangles to the larger triangles is 445/45. The height of cliff is 10 x 445/45 = 4450/45 = 98.888...
14. The triangle has been subdivided into triangles that are similar to the original triangle. Copy each triangle. Label as many side lengths as you can.

All the triangles are equilateral; the large triangle has all three sides measuring 12 inches. The measure of all three sides of the medium triangle is 8 inches, and the measure of all sides of the smallest triangle is 4 inches.

tiles.title: Subdivided equilateral triangle with side lengths

text: 15. The triangles has been subdivided into triangles that are similar to the original triangle. Copy each triangle. Label as many side lengths as you can.

All three triangles are isosceles, as can be seen by the medium triangle with sides 9 m, 18 m, and 18 m. The triangles are all similar because each smaller triangle is nested in the larger triangle. Note the base of each triangle is half the length of its legs. The large isosceles triangle has a leg of 30 m, so its base is 15 m. Also, the smallest triangle has one leg of 12 m, so its other leg is also 12 m and its base is 6 m.

tiles.title: Subdivided Isosceles triangle with side lengths

text: 16. The triangle has been subdivided into triangles that are similar to the original triangle. Copy each triangle. Label as many side lengths as you can.

First, determine the length of the base of the large triangle. The length of the base should be 36cm. You can determine the missing side of the small triangle by dividing 39cm by the scale factor of 3, which should result in the missing side for the small triangle, 13cm.

tiles.title: Subdivided right triangle with side lengths

text: Connections
17. In the figure, lines L1 and L2 are parallel.
a. Use what you know about parallel lines to find the measures of angles a through g.
b. List all pairs of supplementary angles in the diagram.

Students may list any combination of angles as long as the pairs sum to 180°. Reference the answers in part a. For example, angles a and b, a and c, a and g, and a and e are all pairs of supplementary angles.
18. Barnaby’s math and science test scores for the first semester are represented with these box-and-whisker plots. How would you compare his achievement in the two classes?

Answers will vary. Students might say that the median in science is 67 while in math it is 81. Students might notice that the range for his science test scores is 91 and the range for his math test scores is 63, showing more variability in science than in math. Students may talk about how the highest scores were about the same, with 91 (science) and 100 (math), but the lowest scores were not as close, with 0 in science and 37 in math.
19. The following right triangles are similar.
a. Find the length of side RS.
6 m; Since the scale factor from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle is 2, side RS is 3 m x 2= 6 m
b. Find the length of side RQ.
10 m; The corresponding side of RQ is BC. 5 m x 2 = 10 m
c. The measure of angle x is about 40°. If the measure of angle x were exactly 40°, what would be the measure of angle y?
d. Use your answer from ACE 19c to find the measure of angle R. Explain how you can find the measure of angle y.

50°; Since the sum of the angles in triangle STR is 180°, The measure of angle R is equal to 180° - 80° - 50° = 50°. Because the triangles are similar, the angle C is also 50°, since it corresponds to angle R.
e. Angle x and angle y are complementary angles. Find two additional pairs of complementary angles in Triangles ABC and QRS.
Angles R (50°) and Q (40°) are complementary, and angles C and B are complementary.
20. For ACE 20a-f, find the number that makes the fractions equivalent.

Students may have a couple ways of solving these problems. Below is one possible solution for part (d). Similar thinking can apply to all parts.

The scale factor that takes 8 to 2 is 1/4. Therefore, you need 1/4 of 12, which is 3.

a. 2 x 3 = 6

b. 5 x 4 = 20

c. 4 x 2 = 8

d. 12 x 1/4 = 3

e. 3 x 20 = 60

f. 6 x 2.5 = 15

21. For ACE 21a-f, suppose you copy a figure on a copier using the given scale factor. Find the scale factor from the original figure to the copy in decimal form.

a. 200%

b. 50%

c. 150%

d. 125%

e. 75%

f. 25%

a. 200/100 = 2

b. 50/200 = 0.5

c. 150/100 = 1.5

d. 125/100 = 1.25

e. 75/100 = 0.75

f. 25/100 = 0.25
22. For ACE 22a-d, tell whether the figures are mathematically similar. Explain your reasoning. If the figures are similar, give the scale factor from the left figure to the right figure.

tiles.title: Transformed figures a, b, c, d

text:
a. The birds are not similar since the ratio of base length of the larger figure to the base length of the smaller figure is not the same as the ratio of the height of the larger figure to the height of the smaller figure.

b. The figures are similar because the ratio of base length of the larger figure to the base length of the smaller figure is the same as the ratio of the height of the larger figure to the height of the smaller figure. Or, for both width and height the same reduction scale is applied; so, the figures are similar. The scale factor is about 0.7.

c. The figures are not similar because the height of the first figure is reduced by about 56%, while the width is reduced by a smaller percent.

d. The lighthouses are not similar because the height is enlarged but the width is reduced.
23 True or False: All squares are similar. Explain.

True. The corresponding angles will always be equal to each other since they are all 90°, and the ratio of any two sides of a square is 1. Alternatively, students might notice that if they choose any side of one square and any side of the other square, the scale factor must be the same, regardless of which sides they choose.
24. True or False: All rectangles are similar. Explain.
False. While the angles of any two rectangles will be the same (90°), it is not the case that the ratios of the sides will be equal.
True or False: If the scale factor between two similar shapes is 1, then the two shapes are the same size. Explain.

True. The fact that there is a consistent scale factor implies that the shapes are similar, and so the corresponding angle measures are equal. The fact that the scale factor is 1 means that the side lengths are unchanged. Equal angle measures and equal side lengths yield congruent figures.
26. a. Suppose the following rectangle is reduced by a scale factor of 50%. What are the dimensions of the reduced rectangle?
4 cm by 6 cm; 50% is equal to 1/2. So, 8 cm x 1/2 = 4 cm and 12 cm x 1/2 = 6 cm
b. Suppose the reduced rectangle from ACE 26a is reduced again by a scale factor of 50%. What are the dimensions of the new rectangle? Explain your reasoning.

2 cm by 3 cm; When you reduce a figure by 50%, you need to make each side length half of the corresponding side length of the original. Since the first reduction of 50% resulted in a rectangle with dimensions of 4 centimeters and 6 centimeters, you need to find half of 4 centimeters and half of 6 centimeters. The dimensions should be 2 centimeters and 3 centimeters.
c. How does the reduced rectangle from ACE 26b compare to the original rectangle from ACE 26a?

The rectangle is 1/16 the size of the original rectangle. The dimensions of the new rectangle are 1/4 the lengths of the original rectangle.

Note: One thing students often have difficulty with conceptually, is that multiplying by a number smaller than 1 reduces the original. Multiplication is usually taught as a "makes larger" operation in the elementary grades. This concept makes the new world of rational numbers harder for students to enter. Suppose you take a piece of rope that is 12 m long and reduce its length by a factor of 0.5 (or 1/2). The new length of the rope is 6m. Suppose you reduced the new length of the rope by a factor of 0.5 again. The length of the rope is 3 m. A physical model of what is happening to the rope is shown.

27.

Multiple Choice

What is the value of x? The diagram is not to scale.

tiles.title: Right triangle with missing side length

text:
A. 3 cm

B. 10 cm

C. 12 cm

D. 90 cm
B; Since 7.5 x 4 = 30, the scale factor from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle is 4. So, x = 2.5 x 4 = 10
28. Find the missing side length. The diagram is not to scale.

tiles.title: Obtuse triangle with missing side length

text: 12cm; Since 7.5 x 1.5 = 11.25, the scale factor from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle is 1.5 (or 3/2). So, a = 8 x 1.5 = 12
29. Find the missing side length. The diagram is not to scale.

tiles.title: Equilateral triangle with missing side length

text: 9cm; Since 10 x 3/4 = 7.5, the scale factor from the larger triangle to the smaller triangle is 3/4. So, b =12 x 3/4 = 9.
30. Copy polygons A-D into a Sketch Tile or Coordinate Grid Tile. Draw line segments that divide each of the polygons into four congruent polygons that are similar to the original polygon.
Extensions
31. Trace each shape. Divide each shape into four smaller, identical pieces that are similar to the original shape.

tiles.title: Shapes A,B,C divided into 4 congruent pieces

text: 32. You can subdivide figures to get smaller figures that are mathematically similar to the original. The mathematician Beniot Mandelbrot called these figures fractals. A famous example is the Sierpinski triangle.
a. Follow the steps for making the Sierpinski triangle until you subdivide the original triangle three times.
b. Describe any patterns you observe in your figure.

Answers will vary. Possible answer: At each step, the side length of the new triangle is 1/2 the side length of the triangle from the previous step. The area of the new triangle is 1/4 the area of the triangle of the previous step. The number of new shaded triangles obtained at each step follows the following pattern: 1, 3, 9, 27, ... , 3ⁿ (for the n + 1st step)
c. Mandelbrot used the term self-similar to describe fractals like the Sierpinski triangle. What do you think this term means?

Self-similar means that the original figure is similar to a smaller part of itself. You can apply a reduction to the original figure and obtain a new figure that is the same as a part of the original figure.

33. The midpoint of a line segment is a point that divides the segment into two segments of equal length. Draw a figure on the following grid by following these steps:

Step 1: Draw a large square.

Step 2: Mark the midpoint of each side.

Step 3: Connect the midpoints, in order, with four line segments to form a new figure. (The line segments should not intersect inside the square.)

Step 4: Repeat Step 2 and 3 three more times. Work with the newest figure each time.

a. What kind of figure is formed when the midpoints of the sides of a square are connected?
Another square. A sample drawing is below. The first, second, and fifth figures are shown.

tiles.title: Square with midpoints of sides connected

text: b. Find the area of the original square you drew in Step 1.
Answers will vary depending on how large of a square they drew.
c. Find the area of each of the new figures that were formed.
Answers will vary, but each square should have 1/2 the area of the square before it.
d. How do the areas change between successive figures?
At each step, the area of the new square is 1/2 the area of the previous square.
e. Are there any similar figures in your final drawing? Explain.
All the squares are similar to each other. Also, all the triangles are similar to each other.
34. Start with an equilateral triangle. Repeat the directions in ACE 33. Connect three line segments at the midpoints to form a new triangle each time.
a. Another equilateral triangle is formed. A sample drawing is below. The first, second, and third figures are shown.

b. Answer will vary depending on how large a triangle they draw

c. The answer should be 1/4 area of the original triangle

d. At each step, the area of the new triangle is 1/4 the area of the previous triangle

e. All the triangles in the figures are similar to each other
35. Suppose Rectangle A is similar to Rectangle B and to Rectangle C. Can you conclude that Rectangle B is similar to Rectangle C? Explain. Use drawings and examples to illustrate your answer.

Yes. Rectangle B is similar to Rectangle C. Possible explanation: Because Rectangle A is similar to Rectangle B, the ratio of the short side of Rectangle A to the long side of Rectangle A is the same as the ratio of the short side of Rectangle B to the long side of Rectangle B. Because Rectangle A is similar to Rectangle C, the ratio of the short side of Rectangle C to the long side of Rectangle C must equal to his same ratio. This means the ratio between sides in Rectangle C equals the ratio between sides in Rectangle B, making Rectangles C and B similar.
36. Song makes a copy of the poster below.

a. She presses the 50% button on the copy machine. Now the length and width of the poster are each half of their original sizes. Song thinks that if she enlarges the copy by 150%, the new copy will be the same as the original. Is she correct?
Song's conjecture is incorrect. After the first reduction her copy will be 4.5 in x 6 in. When she enlarges it by 150%, it will be 6.75 in x 9 in. This is 50% larger than the original copy.

b. Suppose Song had done the opposite in ACE 36a, first enlarging the poster by 150%, and then reducing the copy by 50%. Will the final copy be the same size as the original? Will it be the same size as the copy made in part ACE 36a?
After the enlargement, her copy will be 13.5 in x 18 in. Reducing this by 50% produces a copy 6.75 in x 9 in. This is the same as in part a., but still smaller than the original.
c. Song uses the same process from parts ACE 36a and ACE 36b with a different-sized poster. Does she get similar results?

Yes. The results are similar. Using the method in part a., the scale factor is 1/2, then the copy is enlarged by a scale factor of 3/2. The sides of the final copy are 1/2 x 3/2, or 3/4 the original size. If the process is reversed, the same result occurs because 3/2 x 1/2 = 3/4
d. Song applied a scale factor of 25% to shrink the original poster. Now she wants to get the poster back to the original size. What scale factor should she use? Explain your reasoning.
Song should choose to enlarge the original by 400%, or a scale factor of 4. This would "undo" the reduction by 25%, or scale factor 1/4, because 4 x 1/4 = 1
e. Suppose Song had used 75% and 125% in parts ACE 36a and ACE 36b instead of 50% and 150%. What would have happened?

Answer will vary.

The shape will be similar to the original, because all of the side lengths are changing by the same amount and the angles stay the same. However if you copy a shape at 75% then 125% will not get back to the original size. For example, we might have a square with sides of 100cm. If we copy at 75%, the sides will be 75 cm. Then, if we copy that at 125%, the sides will be 93.95 cm. If we use 75% then 125% on Song’s poster, we get a rectangle that is 10.8 inches by 8.4375 inches.

f. What general statements can you make about applying any pair of two scale factors one after the other? Consider a pair of two enlargements, a pair of two reductions, and a pair consisting of one enlargement and one reduction.

Answers will vary. Possible answers may include: Reversing the order of the scale factors results in the same final copy; Two reductions result in a copy smaller than either of the reductions would produce on its own; Two enlargements result in a copy larger than either of the enlargements would produce on its own; A reduction paired with an enlargement could result in a copy larger than, smaller than, or the same size as the original. You can make a copy the same size as the original if you apply an enlargement or reduction and its reciprocal.
